Dear Mr. Fernandez:
Report for the above referenced facility completed on 3/4/2022. Due to the violations, a
written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing
statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP and DHHS Policy. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have
training in and maintain a current certification in first aid
from the American Heart Association or the American Red
Cross or other institution approved by the department.
1 of 6 open foster home files reviewed contained documentation that a foster
parent's CPR & First Aid training lapsed for approximately 1 month before being
renewed.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(1) An agency shall recommend to the department the
appropriate licensing action consistent with facts
contained in the foster home evaluation and any
special evaluations.
1 of 6 open foster home files reviewed contained documentation that a foster home
was in violation of the emergency procedures rule; however, the home was found in
full compliance and no CAP was required.
REPEAT VIOALTION ESTABLISHED
2021 Renewal Inspection Report dated 2/18/20, CAP Approved 3/6/20

ADM 1030 ADOPTION CASE RECORD RETENTION
After adoption finalization, all adoption records are closed. The
records must be kept in separate locked files and shall not be open
to inspection or copying, except as stated in disposition of records
in this item.
For both MDHHS and contracted adoption agency cases, the local
MDHHS office or contracted agency must retain all adoption case
records for one year after finalization of the adoption. One year
(between 12-13 months) past the adoption finalization date, a
contracted adoption agency must send the original record to the
local MDHHS office; copies must not be maintained by the
contracted adoption agency; see licensing rule R400.12713-
Adoption Placement Record.
The local MDHHS office must forward all records (both MDHHS
adoptions and contracted agency adoptions) to MDHHS central
office within three months of receipt of file. The contracted
5

adoption agency or local MDHHS office must not retain any
adoption records of MDHHS-supervised children or dispose of
them in any way other than that described in this policy.
Records must be sent to:
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
Document Control Section
235 S. Grand Avenue
P.O. Box 30037
Lansing, Michigan 48909
Following the finalization of adoption, adoptive family files must be
retained in the local MDHHS office or contracted adoption agency
for three years and may be destroyed after the three-year period.
Any Criminal History Records Information (CHRI) must be
maintained and destroyed as outlined in SRM 200, Fingerprinting.
The office has a locked file cabinet in which adoption files are located. These files
have reportedly not been purged/maintained for at least 1 year.
FOM 722-06B FTM Types & Timeframes
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption:
At least three business days prior to a planned change of
placement or no later than three business days after an
unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting, step-down
from a residential or hospital setting, return from AWOLP, or
request for change in foster home/relative placements
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
is used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns
and the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the
family during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within seven business days of the
FTM.

FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check
yes or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review,
and I will have the opportunity to express my
disagreement with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan when the information is
presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign
the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify, and
document actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or
youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the
electronic case record within 30 days of the report date.

FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
Initial Medical Passport
For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport must
be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's placement date
to the following:
• Foster care provider. • Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
Updated Medical Passport
An updated medical passport is provided to:
Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward. -Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement. The child’s
8

foster care provider -At or prior to each placement. -Quarterly.
Older youth/young adults: -Upon initial independent living
placement (youth aged 16 and over).
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
4 of 11 files reviewed did not contain all required Medical Passports with signatures.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
- If it is necessary for initial paperwork/agreements to be mailed to a borrowed
foster family, a corresponding email/phone contact must be documented and
electronically signed by the family to verify that the family was oriented to the
documents for which their signatures are being requested.
- Documents uploaded using the newest iphone updates must be checked to
ensure they can be opened within MiSACWIS.
- When youth are in parental placements, that parent is considered the caregiver
per policy requirements and must still provide the agency with medical/dental
documentation.
- When reviewing contacts in service plans, be sure to ensure that all of the
appropriate members are entered, and all check boxes are completed accurately.
- Closing Action Summaries must be completed within 3 days of the program
closure/case closure for each case. Program closure and case closure occur
simultaneously if there are no open child welfare programs. The program must
remain open until a written court order is received. Additionally, services must be
continued to be offered to the family until the program type is closed and the
efforts to provide those services are to be documented on the action summary.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
- When medical documents are received as password protected from a local
hospital, those documents should be printed and uploaded rather than uploading
them into the system as password protected as the MiSACWIS system is secure.
-
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were 2 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
9

licensing period.
The agency completed through and complete investigations and made
appropriate findings and recommendation.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
2021 Renewal Inspection Report dated 2/18/20, CAP Approved 3/6/20. Overall,
the facility is in compliance with CAP based on the improvement to the
previous areas of repeat non-compliance during this inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment – The Chief Administrator Assessment was
reviewed, and the assessment did identify some areas of non-compliance which were
appropriate and accurate based on the inspection findings.
Interviews – The staff members interviewed reported feeling supported by their co-
workers and superiors. They reported the use of checklists and other mechanisms
developed after last year’s inspection to improve compliance.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified safety concern in 1 home as follows:
Safety Alert: The family was utilizing space heaters to heat the bedrooms. The wood
burner did not have a barrier. The foster parent could not explain why a smoke
detector was beeping on and off during the home visit, stating it was hardwired.
Resolution: I reviewed a safety plan signed by the family and agency on 3/2/22
stating that the family would not use the space heaters in the home and that the local
office would provide appropriate heating units for the family. On 3/4/2022 I reviewed
receipts provided by the local office for electric panel wall heater being delivered to
the foster home. I reviewed a safety plan signed by the family and agency on 3/2/22
stating that the children would not be allowed unsupervised in the room with the wood
burner until a safety gate was installed. On 3/4/2022 I reviewed receipts provided by
the local office for a child barrier gate being delivered to the foster home. I reviewed a
safety plan signed by the family and agency on 3/2/22 stating that the family would
install a functioning smoke detector. On 3/4/2022 I reviewed a photo of a properly
installed smoke detector, which had been provided by the local office.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be
issued a renewal of their regular license.
